Fig. 1 N2 adsorption (closed pattern)/desorption (open pattern) isotherms (a) and pore size distributions (b) of reduced catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of fresh catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Electrical signals of the CH4/CO2 DBD: (a) without catalyst, (b) with NiC700 catalyst; (c) Lissajous figure of plasma-alone and plasma-catalysis systems (Total feed flow of 50 ml min−1, CH4/CO2 molar ratio = 1:1, discharge power of 45 W). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Comparison of CH4 and CO2 conversions under the three modes catalyst (Total feed flow of 50 ml min−1, CH4/CO2 molar ratio = 1:1; Catalyst: NiC700; The reaction temperature: 270 °C; Plasma alone and Plasma-catalysis: discharge power of 45 W). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Effect of the catalysts at different reduction temperature on (a) Conversion of CH4 and CO2, (b) Selectivity and (c) Yield of H2 and CO, and (d) H2/CO molar ratio (Total feed flow of 50 ml min−1, CH4/CO2 molar ratio = 1:1, discharge power of 45 W). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Effect of the catalysts at different reduction temperature on the total energy efficiency of the plasma reforming process (Total feed flow of 50 ml min−1, CH4/CO2 molar ratio = 1:1, discharge power of 45 W). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Comparison the physical properties of fresh and spend catalyst. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distributions (a), XRD patterns (b) and SEM images ((c) fresh, (d) spent) of the NiC700 catalyst. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 FT-IR spectra of (a) fresh and (b) spent catalyst. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 TG-DTG profile of the NiC700 catalyst ((a) fresh, (b) spent). Fig. 9 Scheme 1 Schematic of experimental setup. Scheme 1 Table 1 Physicochemical characteristics of reduced catalysts. Hubei Key Laboratory for Efficient Utilization and Agglomeration of Metallurgic Mineral Resources Wuhan University of Science and Technology Wuhan 430081 PR China Graphical abstract In this paper, the dry reforming of methane and carbon dioxide (DRM) under plasma assisted with nickel (Ni)/activated carbon (AC) catalyst was investigated. In order to determine the synergistic effect of plasma and catalyst, DRM under plasma without catalyst, catalyst alone, and plasma assisted with catalyst was separately studied. The experimental results demonstrated that the highest catalytic activity was achieved when DRM was run under plasma combined with Ni/AC catalyst, and carbon dioxide (64.6%) and methane (65.7%) conversion, as well as the yield of hydrogen (27.9%), carbon monoxide (32.5%) were obtained. Moreover, the AC reduced at 700 °C was regard as the optimum support for DRM, NiC700 under plasma condition exhibited the best performance of DRM ascribed to its mesopores structure, higher specific surface area, and stronger metal-support interaction (SMSI) between Ni and AC support. Keywords Plasma-catalytic Synergistic effect Dry reforming of methane (DRM) Ni-based catalyst Activated carbon 1 Introduction The constantly reducing usability of fossil fuels, in combination with the need to decrease greenhouse gas emissions, has given rise to the necessity of developing sustainable energy sources through greenhouse gas as raw materials [1–6]. Dry reforming of methane (DRM) with CO2 has the advantageous of utilizing two greenhouse gases as the reactants, which has been paid more attention by many researchers [7–12]. Conventional thermal process requires high energy consumption due to the thermodynamic barrier of the reaction CH4 + CO2 → 2CO + 2H2 ΔH298k = 247 kJ mo l − 1 . Furthermore, the sintering and coke deposition of the catalyst due to the high reaction temperature would deactivate the catalyst, which would limit the widely application of the thermal process [13–16]. The non-thermal plasma (NTP) can generate many active groups such as O*, OH* and O3, which are easy to react with the reactants. Thus, the energy barrier of the reaction was reduced, and the reaction of DRM can occur at a lower temperature [17–21]. However, the selectivity of DRM or the H2/CO ratio was difficult to be manipulated in a non-catalytic NTP system. Moreover, the specific energy density required for the non-catalytic reactor is quite high [22]. Plasma-catalytic processes have been reported as a potential alternative to the conventional thermal process and non-catalytic NTP process [23–26], which stems from the fact that there was a synergistic effect of plasma and catalyst. Hence, the yield and selectivity of the target products were improved [27–29]. In addition, Ni-based catalyst has been perceived as one of the most promising choices in the DRM reaction in that their high activity and low cost [30,31]. For instance, Tu et al. [32] investigated the activity of Ni/γ-Al2O3 during the plasma-catalytic DRM process. CH4 conversion was as high as 56.4%, H2 yield reached to 17.5% and energy efficiency was only 0.32 mmol/kJ in their experiment. Mei and co-workers [33] also proved there was synergistic effect between plasma and catalyst during the reforming process, which was conducive to the improvement of the reactant conversion, and the selectivity or yield of the target product, as well as the energy efficiency. Among Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni/MgO, Ni/SiO2, and Ni/TiO2, Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was regarded as the optimum catalyst due to its high activity. The reason could be like that the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited higher specific surface area, and NiO was smaller and dispersed more uniformly. Carbon-based materials, such as activated carbon (AC), possessed the characteristics like low cost, large surface area, excellent stability and chemical inert [34,35]. Additionally, the pore size distribution and surface chemical properties of carbon materials can be easily modified [36]. Recently, carbon materials obtained considerable attention due to not only as a catalyst support but also as a catalyst for several heterogeneous reactions (i.e., hydrogenation [37], oxidation [38], and halogenation [39]). Sun et al. [36] investigated the effect of different AC supported Co catalysts on thermal DRM process, and they observed that the highest CH4 (92%) and CO2 (98%) conversion occurred at 900 °C, respectively. However, up-to-date and to the best of our knowledge, few studies about Ni/AC catalysts in the plasma-catalyst system for DRM reaction were reported. Herein, a dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) reactor was located in a horizontal tube furnace for the DRM process at three modes: catalysis-alone, plasma-alone and plasma-catalysis. Moreover, the effect of Ni/AC catalysts prepared at different reduction temperature (400, 600, 700, 800, and 900 °C) on the performance such as CO2 and CH4 conversion, the yield and selectivity of CO and H2 during DRM process was investigated in the plasma-catalyst reactor. Ni/AC catalysts were characterized in order to further discover the reaction mechanisms. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Ni/AC catalyst A commercial AC was provided by HTC filter material Co. Ltd. (Henan, China) and crushed to 1.0–1.5 mm. AC was firstly impregnated with 0.1 M KOH solution to get rid of acidic impurity. After the agitation for 1.0 h, the mixture was kept for 10 h and dried at 110 °C for 6 h in a ventilated oven. Then, the mixture was calcinated at 650 °C for 1 h under N2 protective atmosphere. After the calcination, the samples were washed with the distilled water until pH = 7 ± 0.05. Finally, the samples were dried at 110 °C for 10 h and used as the support of catalyst. The proximate analysis of AC was summarized in Table S1. Nickel nitrate was used as the precursor of metal, and the predetermined amount of AC was added to nickel nitrate solution. After the agitation for 60 min, the mixture was dried at 105 °C overnight, then the 10% Ni/AC catalysts (mole content) were obtained. Before the reforming reaction, the sample was reduced by carbon thermal reduction method using N2 flow (50 ml·min−1) at the different temperature (400, 600, 700, 800, and 900 °C) for 1 h in the tube furnace, and then cooled to the room temperature under nitrogen. Finally, the prepared catalysts were denoted as NiC400, NiC600, NiC700, NiC800 and NiC900, respectively. 2.2 Characterization The specific surface area and pore size of Ni/AC catalysts were analyzed at 77 K on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 analyzer (USA). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) analysis was conducted to determine the adsorption of CH4 and CO2 on the catalyst surface (BRUKER TENSOR Ⅱ, Germany). X-ray diffraction (XRD) profiles of the catalysts were recorded by an X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku RINT 2000, Cu-Kα radiation, Japan). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM; ZEISS Merlin) was used to know the morphology of catalysts. The coke deposition on the spent catalysts was analyzed in air atmosphere using a simultaneous thermal analyzer (STA 449 F3, Germany). 2.3 Plasma-catalytic tests The experiments were conducted in a coaxial packed-bed DBD reactor, as shown in Scheme 1 . A quartz tube with an inner diameter of 16 mm was used as the reactor. A stainless-steel mesh with a length of 50 mm was served as the negative electrode, which was covered the outside of the quartz reactor. A stainless-steel rod (12 mm diameter) as the positive electrode was located in the axis of the quartz reactor. AC power supply was used to supply the high voltage. The maximum peak-to-peak voltage was 30 kV, and the frequency was 5–12 kHz. Meanwhile, the work voltage was recorded by a high voltage probe (Testec, HVP-15HF, 1000:1), and the work current was online analyzed through a Bergoz instrumentation (Bergoz CT-E0.5) [40]. In all runs, the power was kept at 45 W calculated from Q–U Lissajous method. The flow rates of CH4 and CO2 were controlled by mass flow meters, and the total flow rate was 50 ml min−1. During the experiments, the molar ratio of CH4 and CO2 was kept at 1.0 (no dilution). In the case of plasma-alone mode, no catalyst was used, and the reforming reaction was initiated by only plasma. Plasma will produce heat energy, which keep the temperature of the discharge zone at 270 ± 5 °C (measured by a fiber optical thermometer, Omega FOB 102, USA). In the catalysis-alone mode, 0.25 g fresh catalyst was online reduced at predetermined temperature. After the reduction, the feed gases were shifted and the reforming reaction was conducted at 270 °C without plasma. The reactor in this case was electricity heated and measured by a thermocouple. In the plasma-catalytic mode, the same mass fresh catalysts were used and the reduction process was also same with the above step, except for the application of plasma in this run. The components and concentration of tail gases were analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7820A, USA) equipped with a TCD detector (PoraBOND Q column) and FID detector (molecular sieve-packed column). In this paper, each run was repeated three times and the average data was used. In this paper, CH4 and CO2 conversion (X) were defined as Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) X C H 4 % = CH 4 in − CH 4 out mol CH 4 in mol × 100 (2) X CO 2 % = CO 2 in − CO 2 out mol CO 2 in mol × 100 The selectivity of CO and H2 were described as Eqs. (3) and (4). Moreover, the yield (Y) of the products could be obtained according to Eqs. (6)–(8). (3) S CO % = CO produced mol CO 2 in − CO 2 out + CH 4 in − CH 4 out mol × 100 (4) S H 2 % = H 2 produced mol 2 × CH 4 in − CH 4 out mol × 100 (5) S C x H y % = x × C x H y produced mol CO 2 in − CO 2 out + CH 4 in − CH 4 out mol × 100 (6) Y CO % = CO ( produced ) mol CO 2 in + CH 4 in mol × 100 (7) Y H 2 % = H 2 produced mol 2 × CH 4 in mol × 100 (8) Y C x H y % = x × C x H y ( produced ) mol CO 2 in + CH 4 in mol × 100 The H2/CO molar ratio of the product could be calculated by Eq. (9). The balance of carbon could be obtained from Eq. (10). Finally, the energy efficiency of this plasma-catalyst system was described as Eq. (11) [28]. (9) H 2 CO = H 2 produced mol CO produced mol (10) B c a r b o n % = CH 4 out + CO 2 out + CO out + 2 × C 2 H 6 out mol CH 4 in + CO 2 in mol × 100 (11) E ( m m o l k J − 1 ) = { [ CO 2 ( in ) − CO 2 ( out ) ] + [ CH 4 ( in ) − CH 4 ( out ) ] } ( m m o l s − 1 ) D i s c h arg e p o w e r ( W ) Here, CO2 (in) was the total quantity of feeding CO2 from the inlet, and CO2 (out) the total quantity of CO2 in the tail gas, CH4 (in) the quantity of CH4 in the inlet gas, CH4 (out) the quantity of CH4 in the tail gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural characteristics of the reduced catalyst Fig. 1 showed the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the fresh catalysts. It was observed in Fig. 1(a) that there was a steep slope when P/P 0 was below 0.2, which corresponded to type I isotherm for N2 adsorption. Moreover, type IV isotherm with H4 shaped steep hysteresis loop was also presented in all catalysts when P/P 0 was 0.43–1.0. The above results suggested that there was a hierarchical mesopore/microporous structure in all catalysts. Fig. 1(b) showed that the pore size distribution was narrow, and located in the range of 3.58–4.24 nm. As the reduction temperature was increased from 600 °C to 900 °C, the mesopore amount presented a tendency of first increasing and then decreasing, while the micropores was gradually decreased. Notably, no mesopore was exhibited in NiC400 catalyst. The textural properties of the catalysts were summarized in Table 1 . When the reduction temperature was increased from 400 to 600 °C, the BET specific surface area of the catalysts was increased from 389.3 m2 g−1 to 486.1 m2 g−1. At the same time, the total pore volume was also enhanced from 0.32 cm3 g−1 to 0.35 cm3 g−1. The further increase of the reduction temperature seemed to have limited influence on the total pore volume, while the BET specific surface area would increase to 502.4 m2 g−1 at 700 °C. However, both of the BET specific surface area and total pore volume of the catalyst were decreased when the reduction temperature was above 700 °C. These results might be attributed to the high temperature (<700 °C) could enlarge micropores into mesoporous. Nevertheless, the further increase of temperature (700 °C˜900 °C) would cause the collapsing of partial pore structure of the catalysts [41]. Fig. 2 presented the XRD patterns of the catalysts. The reduced catalysts except for NiC400 had the diffraction peaks at 44.5°, 51.9° and 76.6°, which corresponded to Ni (ICDD 04-0850). Moreover, the diffraction peak of graphite carbon (at 26.7°) was also identified for all the catalysts. The diffraction peaks of NiO (ICDD 78-0552) (2θ = 37.3°, 43.3°, 62.9°, and 75.4°) was only detected in NiC400 catalyst. The above phenomena could be attributed to NiO phase totally reduced to Ni phase under the high reduction temperature (≥600 °C). The Ni particle size was calculated using Scherrer equation [42], as shown in Table 1. The average Ni particle diameter was increased from 7.3 nm to 30.3 nm with the reduction temperature increased from 400 °C to 600 °C, which further increased to 31.7 nm when the reduction temperature was up to 700 °C. However, the crystallite size remained basically unchanged at about 32 nm when the reduction temperature was 900 °C. Hence, it could be speculated that there was a strong metal-active carbon interaction (SMSI) at the high reduction temperature, which was consistent with SEM images of the catalysts (Fig. S1). Wang et al. also reported the similar phenomenon during the thermal catalytic reforming process [43]. 3.2 Plasma-catalytic discharge characteristics Fig. 3 (a) and Fig. 3(b) presented the voltage and current curves with and without catalyst during the dry reforming of CH4 and CO2 at a discharge power of 45 W. As shown in Fig. 3(a), the current curve without catalyst was quasi-sinusoid, and a great amount of current pulses were observed. The current peaks were randomly distributed at the dielectric surface, which correspond to filamentous micro-discharge in DBD. It was reported that the typical radius of these currents was in the range of 100–200 μm [44,45], and the persistence of a single filamentous micro-discharge was about 10 ns. Hence, the CH4/CO2 DBD without catalyst could be regarded as a typical filamentous micro-discharge. Compared with the case without catalyst, the presence of the NiC x catalyst in the discharge slightly decreased the amplitude of the discharge current but increased the displacement current of the DBD (Fig. 3(b)). The results could be ascribed to the reduction of the effective volume of discharge zone due to NiC x catalyst packed into the discharge gap, which effectively suppressed filamentary micro-discharge. Moreover, Ni on the catalyst could conduct electricity and electricity was transferred over the particle surface. Thus, the surface discharges were generated [46]. Lissajous figures with and without NiC x catalyst under 45 W were depicted Fig. 3(c). It was observed that the loading NiC x catalyst in the reactor would change the shape of the Lissajous figure, which also proved that the loading NiC x catalyst would affect the discharge mode. Before and after catalyst loading, the aplite voltages were 29.0 kV pk-pk and 32.4 kV pk-pk under 45 W. Hence, it could be concluded that the current in the case of loading catalyst would be smaller than that of loading no catalyst even the power was the same, which was confirmed by Bergoz instrumentation. 3.3 Comparison at different operating modes Fig. 4 demonstrated the conversion of CH4 and CO2 under catalysis-alone, plasma-alone and plasma-catalysis mode. In the case of catalysis-alone mode (reaction temperature was 270 °C), the DRM is an endothermic reaction, and a high operation temperature is need to attain a high equilibrium of the CH4 and CO2 conversion. In this run, the temperature was only 270 °C, and the conversion of CH4 and CO2 were limited. In the case of plasma-alone, 51.5% CH4 conversion and 42.0% CO2 conversion were achieved. Compared to the reforming in the catalysis-alone or plasma-alone mode, the conversions of CH4 (65.7%) and CO2 (64.6%) were the highest in the plasma-catalysis mode due to the synergy of plasma and catalytic reaction. 3.4 Plasma-catalytic tests Fig. 5 (a) presented the effect of the catalysts reduced at different temperature (from 400 to 900 °C) on the conversion of CH4 and CO2. Table 2 summarized the conversion of CH4 and CO2, selectivity and yield of main products. Moreover, the carbon balance was also presented. Here, H2 and CO were regarded as the main products although a small amount of C2H6 (Fig. S2) was detected. The concentrations of C2H4, C3H8, C3H6 and C2H2 were too low, and they were negligible (Table. S2). The combination of plasma and NiC700 catalyst exhibited the highest CH4 conversion of (62.7–65.7%) and CO2 conversion of (58.3–64.6%) after 90 min’s reaction. In addition, the energy consumption of reforming CO2 was 3834 kJ/mole. The catalyst activity for CH4 and CO2 conversion followed the order: NiC700 ＞ NiC600 ＞ NiC800 ＞ NiC900 ＞ NiC400. Table 3 compared the conversion of CH4 and CO2 in this work with those in literatures. The best conversion of CH4 (74.5%) and CO2 (73.0%) was achieved over Ni/Al2O3-MgO, but the discharge power (100 W) was twice than that of this work (45 W) [47]. Hence, it was speculated that the activity of NiC700 catalyst for plasma reforming in DBD reactor was higher than that in literatures. The enhancement of NiC700 catalytic activity might be achieved by facilitating the mass transport of the reactant/product. NiC700 exhibited the mesoporous and microporous structure, which were beneficial for the diffusion of reactant/product in the catalyst. Sokolov et al. [48] compared the influence of the support morphology (i.e. micropore, mesoporous and macroporous) on the catalyst activity and stability during DRM process, and also thought that the mesoporous catalyst exhibited best excellent catalytic activity and highest stability. As described in Table 1, the reduction temperature had a significant influence on the structure of the catalysts. The reduction temperature’s being increased to 700 °C, the amount of the mesopores was significantly increased. Notably, when the reduction temperature was further increased to 900 °C, the surface area and pore volume of the catalyst was sharply decreased. Hence, the catalyst activity was also decreased despite the presence of mesopores [49,50]. For plasma-catalytic DRM reaction, the nature of Ni-NPs played a key role in plasma-catalytic performance. The mesoporous framework of catalyst could provide more “accessible” Ni active sites for the gaseous reactants and stabilized the Ni particles by the “confinement effect” during the reaction [51,52]. Fig. 5(b) showed the dependence of the reaction time on the selectivity of H2 and CO. Compared with other catalysts, the selectivity of CO and H2 under loading NiC700 catalyst in the DBD reactor was highest, and their average value reached to 49.9% and 42.4% after 90 min’s reaction. At the same time, the combination of plasma with NiC400 catalysts exhibited the lowest H2 selectivity (average value of 38.2%). Moreover, the yield of H2 and CO over NiC700 catalyst was also the highest (Fig. 5(c)), which was the similar tendency of CH4 and CO2 conversion (Fig. 5(a)). Fig. 5(d) presented the variations of H2/CO ratio. The H2/CO ratio was basically stable at 0.87–0.92 for all catalysts after running the reaction for 90 min. Fig. 6 demonstrated the effect of the catalysts on the total energy efficiency. It was obviously observed that the total energy efficiency was improved due to the synergy between plasma and catalytic reaction. In this study, the highest energy efficiency (0.52 mmol kJ−1) was achieved when NiC700 catalyst was loaded in the plasma reforming reactor, followed by NiC600 catalyst. Table 3 also summarized the energy efficiency of plasma reforming under different catalysts. The energy efficiency achieved in our work was much higher than that in literatures. 3.5 characteristics of spent catalyst The spent NiC700 catalyst (after 240 min plasma-catalytic DRM reaction) was characterized by XRD, N2-adsorption and SEM characterization as shown in Fig. 7 . As shown in Fig. 7(a), the mesoporous structure of NiC700 catalyst was well reserved after undergoing the plasma-catalytic DRM reaction. The amount of micropores in the catalyst was significantly decreased, while the amount of mesoporous only was slightly decreased. This phenomenon indicated that the micropores were easily destroyed during the plasma process. In addition, the physical properties of NiC700 catalyst before and after DRM reaction were summarized in Table 4 . Compare with the reduced NiC700 catalyst, the catalyst underwent DRM reaction in plasma reactor resulted in the decrease of BET surface area and the total pore volume, which could be due to the collapse of some micropores. The crystallite size of spent NiC700 catalyst was not significantly changed according to SEM images of NiC700 before and after the reaction (Fig. 7(c) and (d)). Moreover, no obvious new diffraction peaks were observed in the spent catalyst in Fig. 7(b). These phenomena proved that the catalyst was not obviously deactivated after running the reforming reaction for 240 min. Fig. 8 presented FT-IR spectra of all fresh and spent catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8(a), all fresh catalysts had the similar peaks and peak intensity. The broad band at 3440 cm−1 as well as peak at 3730 cm−1 were assigned to the bending vibration of H2O and OH group [40,54]. The absorption peaks at 2358 cm−1, 1635 cm−1 and 670 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibrations of CO [55], stretching vibrations of CC [56] and bending vibration of CH [57], respectively. Compared to the fresh catalysts, the peak of all spent catalysts had no obviously changes (Fig. 8(b)), while the intensity of peaks at 2358 cm−1 (CO) and 670 cm−1 (CH) were significantly enhanced. Moreover, the intensity of peaks at 2358 cm−1 (CO) and 670 cm−1 (CH) followed the order: NiC700 ＞ NiC600 ＞ NiC800 ＞ NiC900 ＞ NiC400. The results indicated that the NiC x catalysts, especially NiC700 catalyst had a strong adsorption capability of CO2 and CH4, which prolonged the residence time of reactants in the catalyst and benefited to improve the conversions of CO2 and CH4. The coke deposition on the spent catalyst (NiC700 catalyst after 240 min plasma-catalytic DRM reaction) was analyzed by TG-DTG, as shown in Fig. 9 . In general, the deposited coke had three types of morphology, including the active carbonaceous species (Cα), less active carbonaceous species (Cβ) and inactive carbonaceous species (Cγ), which could be identified according to the oxidation temperature from TGA profile [58,59]. As shown in Fig. 9, both of fresh and spent NiC700 catalysts underwent a significant mass loss at 355–680 °C, which was related to the oxidation of active carbon into CO and CO2. The weight loss of the fresh and spent catalysts were 39.23% and 39.71%, respectively. TG/TGA indicated that AC support had no obviously change during plasma-catalytic DRM reaction, and it could be speculated that less active Cβ species were generated. Compared with the fresh NiC700 catalyst, the peak at about 310 °C in the spent NiC700 catalyst was observed, which was the characteristic of the active Cα species and usually existed as amorphous carbon. It could be ascribed to the coke deposition in the plasma-catalytic DRM process, as could be seen from only an 85.2% carbon balance. In the plasma-catalytic DRM reaction, CH4 dissociation or gas phase reactions as well as the surface reactions driven by plasma could cause the formation of coke deposition. In the gas phase reactions (Fig. S3), the CH x (x = 1–3) radicals were formed from the dissociation of CH4 according to Eqs. (12)–(14) [28,60], followed by the recombination of CH x and generated higher hydrocarbons or further decomposition. (12) CH 4 + e − → CH 3 + H + e − (13) CH 4 + e − → CH 2 + H 2 + e − (14) CH 4 + e − → CH + H 2 + H + e − When high energy electrons (＞14 eV) existed, solid carbon could be formed through Eqs. (15)–(18) and deposited on the surface of the catalyst [32]. (15) CH 4 + e − → C + 2 H 2 + e − (16) C H 3 + e − → C + H 2 + H + e − (17) CH 2 + e − → C + H 2 + e − (18) CH + e − → C + H + e − Hence, the dissociation of CH4 on the surface of catalyst was one of the key reaction pathways of carbon formation [61]. In this work, the rate of coke deposition on the catalyst surface was about 2.3 wt. % h−1, which was less than the reported value (3.3 wt. % h−1) obtained in plasma-Ni-K/Al2O3 reforming biogas. However, the future work was still developing a new catalyst with an excellent resistance of carbon deposition. 4 Conclusions In this work, Ni/AC catalyst was prepared by loading Ni on the commercial active carbon through wet impregnation. At the same time, the influence of the reduction temperature on the physical and textural properties of catalysts were investigated. Moreover, the performance of DRM reaction under catalyst alone, plasma without catalyst, plasma-catalyst system was compared. The experimental results demonstrated that the best CO2 and CH4 conversion could be achieved due to the synergistic effect of plasma and catalytic reaction. In this study, the maximum CO2 and CH4 conversion reached to 64.6% and 65.7% in the plasma-NiC700 catalyst system. In addition, the influence of the physical and textural properties of catalysts on the CO2 and CH4 conversion in the plasma-catalyst reactor was also considered. NiC700 exhibited the highest CO2 and CH4 conversions due to the fact that it posed more mesoporous, larger specific surface area and higher pore volume. The stability test demonstrated that the NiC700 catalyst was promising for the plasma-catalytic dry reforming of CO2 and CH4. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, the dry reforming of methane and carbon dioxide (DRM) under plasma assisted with nickel (Ni)/activated carbon (AC) catalyst was investigated. In order to determine the synergistic effect of plasma and catalyst, DRM under plasma without catalyst, catalyst alone, and plasma assisted with catalyst was separately studied. The experimental results demonstrated that the highest catalytic activity was achieved when DRM was run under plasma combined with Ni/AC catalyst, and carbon dioxide (64.6%) and methane (65.7%) conversion, as well as the yield of hydrogen (27.9%), carbon monoxide (32.5%) were obtained. Moreover, the AC reduced at 700 °C was regard as the optimum support for DRM, NiC700 under plasma condition exhibited the best performance of DRM ascribed to its mesopores structure, higher specific surface area, and stronger metal-support interaction (SMSI) between Ni and AC support.
coredata.dc:title: Non-thermal plasma enhanced dry reforming of CH4 with CO2 over activated carbon supported Ni catalysts
